newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia nearly sold out of sugar - QSC.
newsitem.headline: Australia nearly sold out of sugar - QSC.

text.p: Nearly all of Australia's 1996/97 season sugar production had been sold despite an over-supplied world sugar market, David Rutledge, chief executive, Queensland Sugar Corp (QSC) said.
This showed customers had a clear preference for Queensland raw sugar, he said in a report in Corporation News, the official newsletter of QSC.

Rutledge said QSC had continued its focus on traditional customers in 1996/97 ending June 30 and expected market share in the key markets of Canada, Japan, South Korea and Malaysia to be maintained or increased.
Increased raw sugar production over the past few years had also enabled the establishment of new export markets, he said.
This year raw sugar was sold to Indonesia and Saudi Arabia for the first time after refineries opened in those countries.
Queensland sugar was also sold to Morocco for the first time since 1981/82, he said.
Exports of Queensland raw sugar in 1996/97 were expected to reach four million tonnes for the first time after record raw sugar production of 4.99 million tonnes, he said.

The record 1996 season raw sugar was produced from a record cane crop of 37.17 million tonnes, up 8.5 percent from the 1995 season production of 4.60 million tonnes from 35.29 million tonnes of cane, he said.
